info.game_comments:
Missing first nine clues.
Final Jeopardy! logo flashes on the game board's monitors instead of the show's logo.

(1, 1).clue: The island of Sumatra in the Indian Ocean was visited by this Italian explorer in about 1292

(3, 1).clue: For most of its 100 plus years, it's been the world's best-selling mouthwash

(5, 1).clue: The name of this popular patio flower comes from Greek "geranos" meaning crane

(6, 1).clue: The World Book says most of these have from 72-96 members & sometimes feature baton twirlers

(1, 2).clue: Baffin, Victoria, & Ellesmere Islands, 5th, 9th, and 10th largest in world, all belong to this country

(3, 2).clue: The best-selling brand of children's vitamins in the U.S. is named for these cartoon characters

(5, 2).clue: This Asian variety of lily is aptly named since it's orange splashed with black

(6, 2).clue: What the "M.B." stands for in your M.B.A. degree

(1, 3).clue: For a while in 1814, this 86-square-mile island was Napoleon's total domain

(3, 3).clue: People spray Chloraseptic to relieve this pain

(5, 3).clue: In March of 1987, a Van Gogh painting featuring these flowers sold for $39,921,750

(6, 3).clue: This small round object made of naphthalene can keep your Dior from disintegrating

(1, 4).clue: The Act of Union in 1707 united 2 kingdoms into this island nation named for the island it was on

(2, 4).clue: An ex-slave was hired to sit on a porch & tell folk tales for 1946 Georgia premiere of this Disney film

(3, 4).clue: It's said a Sumerian clay tablet from 2000 B.C., calling for plant materials, is the oldest one known

(5, 4).clue: From the French "pensee", it's pansy's pensive meaning, even though yours may be far away

(6, 4).clue: Colorful title of Melissa Manchester's 1st Billboard top 40 hit

(1, 5).clue: If you hold you family reunion on Reunion, you're on an island which belongs to this country

(2, 5).clue: He was Judy Garland's companion on the road to Oz & later became her daughter's father-in-law

(3, 5).clue: In the '50s, ads for this hair product warned guys not to use "that greasy kids stuff"

(6, 5).clue: Overwhelming, as with wonder or perplexity

(1, 1).clue: The first permanent English settlement in the American colonies

(2, 1).clue: Upton Sinclair set "The Jungle" not in the third world but in this Second City

(3, 1).clue: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer is equivalent of this U.S, cabinet secretary

(4, 1).clue: He was born Ferenc Liszt, but known by this German version of his 1st name

(5, 1).clue: John Amos got an Emmy nomination for playing this character as an adult in

(1, 2).clue: In 1773, Ben Franklin tested this form of execution & knocked off chickens, a 10-lb. turkey & a lamb

(2, 2).clue: It's the beloved country in Alan Paton's "Cry the Beloved Country"

(3, 2).clue: While Canada is divided into provinces, Australia has 6 of these

(4, 2).clue: Songwriter who emigrated from Russia to New York in the 1890s, which may have inspired the following

(5, 2).clue: This comedian of Lebanese descent, aka Amos Jacobs, was awarded a Congressional Gold Medal for humanitarianism

(6, 2).clue: As the last word in a palindromic phrase, it's what owls might say it's "too hot to" do

(1, 3).clue: In 1843, Mexico said annexation of this as a U.S. state would be equal to a declaration of war

(2, 3).clue: Subtitled "The Memoirs of a Woman of Pleasure", in 1821 it became 1st book tried for sexual obscenity in U.S.

(3, 3).clue: While "Venus" was a #1 hit for Frankie Avalon, no one's had a hit about this, her Greek equivalent

(4, 3).clue: Black composer James A. Bland, born in NYC in 1854, wrote this state song of Virginia

(5, 3).clue: On "The Real McCoys", he was Grandpappy Amos "Head of the clan, he roars like a lion, but he's gentle as a lamb"

(6, 3).clue: French pronoun or French magazine, both concerned with women

(1, 4).clue: Napoleon's grand-nephew, Attorney General Charles Bonaparte, established this U.S. agency in 1908

(2, 4).clue: He died in 1824, leaving unfinished his only 3 novels, "The Trial", "The Castle" & "Amerika"

(3, 4).clue: JFK's equivalent of FDR's "New Deal" and Truman's "Fair Deal"

(4, 4).clue: This native of Washington, D.C. wrote several novels & an autobiography called "Marching Along"

(5, 4).clue: While Andy's occupation was trying to get rich quick, Amos of "Amos & Andy" did this for a living

(6, 4).clue: For Mae West, this "diamond" was a theatrical gem

(1, 5).clue: His 16-minute flight on July 21, 1961 made him the 2nd American in space

(2, 5).clue: 1941 Arthur Koestler novel which showed his disillusionment with Communism

(3, 5).clue: In most Islamic countries, it's the equivalent of the Red Cross

(6, 5).clue: Jahan of India and Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, for example

(0, 0).clue: 1 of 2 letters that begins the names of 6 state capitals, more than any other
